title: Defining atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), its causes, and the role of cholesterol
content: Peter dives deep into the topic of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD)—the number one killer in the developed world. He goes into great detail about the development of atherosclerosis and how it can take hold at a very early age, the role of cholesterol, and the causal factors of ASCVD that determine prevention strategies.

title: The process of developing ASCVD
content: Peter discusses the process of developing ASCVD in three parts, including how early in life it can start to develop, case studies of atherosclerosis and figures showing real pathology, and coronary artery lesions present in autopsies of different age groups.

title: Diagnostic tests to determine the level of arterial damage present—CAC, CTA, CIMT, and more
content: Peter discusses diagnostic tests such as coronary artery calcium scores (CAC) and CT angiograms which help to determine the level of arterial damage present.

title: Calcium scores: keys to understanding and interpreting a CAC score and/or CTA results
content: Peter lays out the keys to understanding and interpreting calcium scores.

title: Key takeaways regarding prevention
content: Peter wraps up the conversation with his key takeaways regarding prevention.

title: The Importance of Understanding Atherosclerosis Early in Life
content: Atherosclerosis is ubiquitous. It’s the only disease that is inevitable, and it limits human longevity. Cancer and dementia, also diseases of old age are not inevitable the way atherosclerosis is. Studies of pathology show ASCVD begins at a young age. What is the most common presentation for a 1st heart attack? Sudden death. A 1st heart attack in over 50% of people is fatal; today this number is a little less but still staggering.

title: The Age Distribution of People Who Have Their 1st Major Adverse Cardiac Event
content: Adverse cardiac events are a heart attack or a stroke (or death). The graph on the right shows total annual events. The 1st 2 sets of bars show the number of events for people under 65. Men are shown in the darker bars comprising slightly below 25% and slightly above 25% of all cardiac events. The implication is that 50% of men who are going to have a cardiac event in their life will have it before the age of 65.

title: Cardiovascular Disease in Women and Men
content: For women, a third of women will have their 1st cardiac event before the age of 65. Almost 25% of these events are in men younger than 54.

title: Understanding Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease (ASCVD)
content: ASCVD is disease state characterized by the deposition or the buildup of cholesterol (sterols) in the artery wall. It begins with a fatty streak that later consolidates into plaques that can ultimately lead to a reduction in blood flow. Reduction in blood flow is called ischemia. Ischemia results in tissue damage to the heart and this is what results in a heart attack. A heart attack can be fatal depending on the amount of cardiac tissue that is damaged from loss of oxygenation.

title: Causes of ASCVD
content: Atherosclerosis is defined by the presence of cholesterol in the artery wall. This is not necessarily related to the measurement of cholesterol in circulation. Patients with cholesterol in their arteries do not necessarily have to have co-aggravating factors such as: high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, family history, smoking. All these things that exacerbate ASCVD.

title: Cholesterol Explained
content: Cholesterol is an organic molecule, a type of lipid. It is not soluble in water. It is a hydrophobic molecule. Cholesterol is about one of the most important molecules in the body. Cholesterol is used for 2 main things: 1 – The cell membrane of every cell in the body contains cholesterol. 2 – Synthesis of many hormones begins with cholesterol, including: cortisol, estrogen, testosterone. It is also essential for the creation of bile acids, necessary to digest food.

title: The Process of Developing ASCVD
content: The endothelium is a 1-cell layer that lines the surface (and protects) the arterial lumen. The arterial lumen is the inside of a blood vessel; this is the area through which blood is flowing. The endothelium has really complex functions. It can modulate vascular tone. The process of developing ASCVD begins with the endothelium. ASCVD is a disease state characterized by the deposition or the buildup of cholesterol (sterols) in the artery wall.

title: The Role of LDL in Atherosclerosis
content: LDL is a lipid transport particle that carries cholesterol in the bloodstream. LDL particles can slip through the cracks in the endothelium and enter the subendothelial space, which is a risk factor for atherosclerosis. Once in the subendothelial space, LDL particles can bind to proteoglycans and undergo chemical reactions that oxidize them. This doesn’t happen to all the LDL particles.

title: Factors Damaging to the Endothelium
content: Uric acid, hyperinsulinemia, elevated glucose levels, and homocysteine are all damaging to the endothelium lining blood vessels. Anything that damages the endothelium is going to increase the likelihood that LDL particles can sneak their way through.

title: The problem and the 1st critical step in ASCVD
content: Peter’s takeaway— retention of LDL in the subendothelial space and its oxidation is the problem and the 1st critical step in ASCVD

title: LDL particles retained in the subendothelial space can be modified or oxidized to become toxic
content: Figure 5.  LDL particles retained in the subendothelial space can be modified or oxidized to become toxic

title: Endothelial cells become dysfunctional and express selections and adhesion molecules
content: Figure 6.  Endothelial cells become dysfunctional and express selections and adhesion molecules.

title: Monocytes are a type of immune cell recruited to the damaged endothelium
content: Figure 7.  Monocytes are a type of immune cell recruited to the damaged endothelium.

title: Damaged endothelial cells release Interleukin-6 and other cytokines
content: Figure 8.  Damaged endothelial cells release Interleukin-6 and other cytokines

title: After stopping at adhesion molecules on damaged endothelium, monocytes enter the subendothelial space
content: Figure 9.  After stopping at adhesion molecules on damaged endothelium, monocytes enter the subendothelial space.

title: Monocytes ingest oxidized LDL particles
content: Figure 10.  Monocytes ingest oxidized LDL particles

title: A fatty streak is formed by the accumulation of enlarged foam cells
content: Figure 11.  A fatty streak is formed by the accumulation of enlarged foam cells.

title: HDL use ABC1 to remove cholesterol from macrophages
content: Figure 12.  HDL use ABC1 to remove cholesterol from macrophages.

title: HDL and Disease Prevention
content: HDL particles use a suction system to suck cholesterol out of macrophages and move it to pre-HDL particles to prevent further damage. HDL removes lipids from the worst place you can have them and takes them elsewhere in the body where they can be used. This is why HDL is thought of as being protective. CETP genes are some of the genes that are modified in people who live an exceptionally long time, centenarians.

title: The Process of Developing ASCVD
content: It’s overly simplistic (and patently wrong) to think that HDL is good cholesterol and LDL is bad cholesterol. You can’t infer anything about risk from a high level of HDL cholesterol. Every intervention that has tried to raise HDL cholesterol pharmacologically has failed to improve outcomes. How HDL works is complex: The functionality of the HDL particle is much more complicated than something we can assess through either their size, their number, or their cholesterol content.

title: Foam Cells and Atherosclerotic Plaque
content: The HDLs fix some of the lipids macrophages have taken in, but in the end the macrophages become more and more engorged with oxidized LDL. Foam cells produce a whole bunch of things that undermine the integrity of the arterial wall leading to more endothelial dysfunction. Chemical signals start to trigger the migration of smooth muscle cells to the area of the injury. Smooth muscle cells try to repair the damage by laying down a matrix to heal the injured wall. This matrix becomes the fibrous cap of the atherosclerotic plaque.

title: The Formation of Atherosclerotic Plaque
content: By the time you’re having events, the process covered so far has happened decades earlier. These enzymes that are upregulated start to dissolve and weaken the plaque cap. This typically occurs at the shoulder regions where the diseased endothelium cells meet healthy endothelial cells. Atherosclerosis should really be viewed as a systemic condition of the entire arterial system.

title: Inflammatory Response and Plaque Formation
content: Smooth muscle cells have migrated to the place of damage. The damage is greatest at the site of these large foam cells. This is incredibly inflammatory. The endothelial barrier is very dysfunctional and is barely holding on for dear life. Now this plaque can start to become obstructive. Lipid rich plaques can become quite unstable and they can rupture, causing really bad things to happen. In figure 17, the plaque at the bottom is unstable. Some lipid is protruding through the cap. If this lipid gets out, it will kick off a coagulation cascade. Platelets will show up. Platelets are in the blood; their job is to stop bleeding if we have an injury.

title: Blood Clot Formation and Heart Attack
content: Platelets serve as a kind of cradle for the coagulation cascade to produce a net of fibrin. Shown as white blobs in figure 18. This leads to a clot. Red blood cells are caught in this net. A nonobstructive plaque can lead to a clinical event after the superimposition of red and white thrombus. This can happen very quickly. This is typically the cause of a heart attack. A heart attack does not occur because the lumen narrowed little by little. Typically there was some narrowing. But it’s the rupture of a plaque that leads to the sudden occlusion of blood flow. That’s why going back to what my pathology professor talked about 25 years ago, a very, very common presentation is sudden death. Those people don’t get a warning. They don’t get to say, “Oh god, I’m really having chest pain walking up the stairs today because I’m slowly losing blood supply to my heart.” People go from being fine to dead if that occlusion occurs in a place where restriction of blood flow is fatal. If it occurs at a very distal point in the blood supply, then it might not cause a fatal heart attack. If it occurs high enough, it can be a “Widowmaker”. A Widowmaker lesion is very, very high in the left main coronary artery. At such a level, if you occlude blood flow, you’re basically robbing the entire left ventricle of blood, which would be, universally fatal.

title: Development of ASCVD
content: How early in life ASCVD can start to develop. 3 big points to remember. 1 – The number of particles in the blood is important. 2 – You want your endothelium to be as healthy as possible. 3 – This takes a very long time to develop. If we’re talking about apoB bearing particles (LDL particles), entering the subendothelial space, getting retained, getting oxidized. This happens very early in life for some individuals. There are studies that demonstrate that this actually starts in utero where the fetus can be exposed to the mother’s lipoproteins. Clinically we would say that this disease manifests during the 4th-6th decades of life. That means it begins when someone is in their 30s, 40s or 50s. We typically see a full decade difference between men and women. This is something where women have a distinct advantage. That’s not true for other diseases; for Alzheimer’s disease women are at a distinct disadvantage. “I think it’s safe to say that if you do an autopsy on most men who die from some other reason in their 30s, you will find evidence of significant atherosclerosis”— Peter Attia.

title: Early Signs of Atherosclerosis
content: Intimal thickening is an early sign of atherosclerosis. Figure 20 shows a more advanced lesion (type IV).

title: Type IV Lesion
content: Figure 20 shows a more advanced lesion (type IV) in the proximal, middle left anterior descending, artery of a 23-year old male victim of homicide. There is an enormous lipid core disrupting the musculoelastic layer above the media layer. The luminal narrowing is not clinically significant.

title: Type IV Lesion in Left Main Coronary Artery
content: Figure 21 shows another type IV lesion in the left main coronary artery of a 19-year old male suicide victim. The extracellular lipid and even the cholesterol in there has been crystallized. This is probably more likely to elicit an immune response.

title: Type V Lesion
content: Figure 22 shows a type V lesion in the proximal (so the upper part of the left anterior descending) artery of a 38-year old male accident victim. This is a much more advanced lesion. The lipid core extends into the media. If this person didn’t die in a car accident, they would probably not live to age 65.

title: Cross Section of the Proximal LAD
content: Figure 23 shows a complete cross section of the proximal LAD from a 24-year old man who died suddenly. If you get a blockage here, you’re dead.

title: Autopsy findings
content: Based on the autopsy, it doesn’t look like he died of a heart attack. This is a type IV lesion that was 1.5 cm long. It starts about a centimeter before the bifurcation of the LAD in the circ. This means it’s a very high lesion.

title: Coronary artery lesions
content: After age 11, the graph starts to steadily climb. By age 40, 70% of people have these types of lesions (types III, IV, and V).

title: Causal factors of ASCVD
content: When thinking about prevention, start with what causes this disease. Cholesterol causes this disease. Other things play a causal role. Hypertension, Smoking, Metabolic health. Metabolic health is perhaps the most important, subtle thing that is not appreciated here.

title: Managing lipids to prevent ASCVD
content: Typical cholesterol panels. The bare bones panel is going to be a total cholesterol, an LDL cholesterol, an HDL cholesterol, and a triglyceride (TG). You should go one step further and measure VLDL cholesterol. This will allow for a non-HDL cholesterol. A non-HDL cholesterol is the sum of all the cholesterol minus the HDL. That’s basically the LDL cholesterol + VLDL cholesterol. Non-HDL cholesterol is always going to be more than LDL cholesterol.

title: Importance of apoB
content: HDLs are important to reduce the risk of atherosclerosis, but measuring cholesterol in them doesn't determine their effectiveness. ApoB is important in determining the probability of LDL particles entering the subendothelial space and causing atherosclerosis. The number of LDL particles is a good predictor of risk, and apoB is the most important metric to predict risk.

title: Biomarkers for predicting risk
content: The full lipid panel, Lp(a), apoB, and APOE are useful biomarkers for predicting risk. However, there are no great biomarkers for assessing how much atherosclerosis is present. Additional measurements such as homocysteine, uric acid, thyroid function, iron, and ferritin factor into how risk is managed.

title: Diagnostic tests for arterial damage
content: CAC and CTA are the most important diagnostic tests to determine the level of arterial damage present. CAC looks at the amount of calcification in the coronary arteries, which is a late stage of healing and a very advanced finding of disease. However, it doesn't tell much about what's happening at the point of calcification.

title: Calcium Score and Atherosclerosis
content: Peter Attia recently got a patient’s calcium score back and it was not a very high number, but it wasn’t 0. The fact that they have a score of, say 15 at one part of their left anterior descending really means nothing about what’s happening there. But that becomes a real global alarm given that person’s age (early 40s). Further, if they have a calcified point right there, they undoubtedly have atherosclerosis elsewhere. The CT angiogram (CTA) is a much better test. A CT scan of the heart (this one is with contrast) captures the calcification. They typically run a dry scan first to look for calcium. But then once the contrast is in, you can see with great illumination the arteries. This gives a better sense of the luminal narrowing and the presence of soft plaque.

title: CIMT and ASCVD
content: CIMT is an ultrasound that’s done of the carotid arteries in the neck. Peter Attia finds this to be a completely unhelpful test for a couple of reasons: 1 – It is so user dependent in terms of the operator. The operator needs amazing technical skill to get a really good look at those carotid arteries. 2 – If you will want to see a change in this, you pretty much have to have the same person doing it again and again. There are no guidelines that are based on a CIMT. Peter prefers a CAC over a CIMT.

title: CAC Score and CHD Risk
content: For many patients, Peter Attia doesn’t bother getting a CAC score if it’s not going to add any benefit to what they’re already doing for risk prevention. The CAC score is not something that you follow serially over time. It’s used a couple times to establish risk. Figure 25 is a table taken from the Family Heart Study, published in 2006. It looked at CAC scores on a little over 3,000 subjects between 2002, 2004. About 400 of these people were clinically diagnosed with CHD. These patients were all asymptomatic at the initial exam. Basically what you’re looking at is calcium score progression to coronary events in people who were asymptomatic at the time of outset. There is a clear relationship between the increase in the calcium score (CAC) and the likelihood of a cardiac event.

title: CAC Scores and Risk
content: A CAC of 0 is used as the unit case. A CAC of 1-49 is generally considered low and is a 1.2 increase in risk over 8 years. A CAC of 50-99 nearly doubles the risk. A CAC of 100-199 has an odds ratio of up to 3.8. By the time the calcium score is 2,000, the odds ratio is 55.7, significantly higher. When Peter had his calcium score measured at age 35 it was 6. 6 is a very low number when the scores go up to 2,000. At age 36 this put him at about the 75th percentile of the population.

title: CAC Scores and Lipids
content: The CAC was really valuable for him because his lipids weren’t that high. Much of that risk was mediated through things that are not easy to measure, such as family history. At the other end of the spectrum, he has patients that are in their 60s who have “ragingly high lipids”, and they’re really hell bent about not taking lipid lowering medication. For them a calcium score becomes a very helpful way to assess whether or not lipid lowering medication should be discussed in greater detail.

title: CAC Scores and CT Angiogram
content: If a patient who’s 70 has a calcium score of zero, even in the presence of high lipids, you might be more willing to acknowledge that this is a person for whom, despite having very high lipids, may have something that’s offering protection. Peter would have this person get a CT angiogram because of all the reasons that calcification alone is not sufficient. He’s want to look at the lumen for evidence of soft plaque. He’s seen people in their 70s who have really normal CTA despite abnormal lipids, but they are the exception.

title: CAC Scores and CT Angiogram
content: Thinking about CAC scores, when is calcium even starting to show up? This is a late stage event. The one at the most right (E) is where you start to see calcification occur. (E) shows a fibrocalcific lesion that can be picked up with a calcium score. The point here is how many people can still be missed. You can still be in A, B, C, D, and have a normal calcium score. Only in E is your calcium score abnormal. But a CT angiogram can pick up A, B, C, D. Every patient and doctor have to make the decision— when is it worth the additional cost and the slight increase in the amount of radiation to have a much better test than one that can only detect E? There’s nothing that’s black and white. It’s not every patient should do this, everyone should do this. It’s dependent on all these different factors, and together, which I think shows the importance of why diving into this and understanding.

title: CAC Scores and Density
content: There’s now evidence to suggest that even the calcium score by itself is not sufficient in terms of just understanding calcium versus no calcium. It turns out that the density of the calcium also matters. If you then look at just the differences in the Hounsfield units at the calcification of the coronary artery, that tells you something. The denser the calcium, the lower the risk.

title: Calcification is not necessarily bad
content: Calcification by itself is not a bad thing. It’s actually a good thing; it’s stabilizing the plaque. It’s just that it’s a harbinger of what’s going on.

title: Cholesterol levels being too low
content: There is no risk from having cholesterol be too low. Even if you shrink the cholesterol in lipoproteins by 50%, you’re only reducing total body cholesterol by 4.5%. The vast majority of cholesterol still resides in peripheral tissue, and that’s where it’s being turned into hormones.

title: Prevention is key
content: ASCVD is very common, but it takes a while to occur. Prevention should be thought of decades in advance. You want to be thinking about this through the lens of not 5 years worth of prevention, but 10, 20, 30 years of prevention.

title: Importance of understanding apoB
content: The other big takeaway is the importance of understanding apoB and why apoB concentration is such an important metric. ApoB captures the risk much better than LDLC, and even non HDLC.

title: Lp(a) is relevant for about 10% of the population
content: We will have an upcoming podcast on Lp(a) to go deep into that topic. Lp(a) is very relevant for about 10% of the population.

title: Lp(a) and Disease Prevention
content: Everybody should know their Lp(a) and if it’s elevated, this opens a whole new Pandora’s box of things to think about prevention-wise

title: Benefits and Considerations of Calcium Scores
content: Calcium scores are really good tests. The CTA is a much better test than the coronary artery calcium (CAC) score; you just have to decide if the additional cost and radiation are worth it. Peter likes the CTA more than the CAC because it’s harder to get fooled. The CAC is a great way to stratify risk, but you’re going to miss a lot of pieces of pathology if they haven’t reached the level of calcification yet.
